cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
when did the eagles win the super bowl
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: 
To determine when the Philadelphia Eagles won the Super Bowl, I need to recall the history of the Super Bowl and the specific years in which the Eagles participated. The Eagles reached the Super Bowl several times, but they won their first and only championship in Super Bowl LII. This game took place on February 4, 2018, where they defeated the New England Patriots.

Answer: The Philadelphia Eagles won the Super Bowl on February 4, 2018.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
when did the eagles win the super bowl
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['The Eagles defeated the New England Patriots by a score of 41–33 in Super Bowl LII at U.S. Bank Stadium in Minneapolis, Minnesota on February 4, 2018, ending the alleged curse.\n', "The Eagles went on to win Super Bowl LII, 41–33. It was the team's first NFL championship since 1960, and first ever Super Bowl win.\n", "On January 23, 2005, the Eagles reached a fourth consecutive conference championship game (the first time this happened in the salary cap era of the NFL). At long last, the Eagles justified the hopes of their long-suffering fan base, defeating Michael Vick's much-hyped Atlanta Falcons, 27-10, sending them to their first Super Bowl in 24 years. The victory sent the city of Philadelphia into wild celebrations.\n", 'On February 4, 2018, the Philadelphia Eagles defeated the New England Patriots in Super Bowl LII 41-33 to win their first Super Bowl in team history, and first championship since the 1960 NFL Championship.\n', 'The Eagles have won four league titles. Three of these were won prior to the start of the Super Bowl era (in 1948, 1949, and 1960). The fourth and most recent championship was won in Super Bowl LII.\n', "This alleged curse supposedly prevented the Philadelphia Eagles franchise from winning a Super Bowl game. The origin of this curse dates back to 1960, when the Eagles defeated Vince Lombardi and the Green Bay Packers in the 1960 NFL Championship Game. This would be the only playoff loss in Lombardi's coaching career. Following Lombardi's death in 1970, the league honored his legacy by naming the Super Bowl trophy after him. This renaming, combined with the Eagles inability to win another championship after their 1960 victory, led some Eagles fans to believe the franchise was cursed by Vince Lombardi; that beating Lombardi meant never winning the trophy named after him. During that time, the Eagles accumulated a lot of playoff heartbreak, including 2 Super Bowl losses to the Oakland Raiders and New England Patriots, and 3 consecutive NFC Championship Game losses from 2001-2003. \n", 'On January 11, 2009, the team defeated the defending Super Bowl champion New York Giants 23–11 en route to their sixth NFC Championship Game. In the NFC Championship, the Eagles made a rally, going from down 24–6 at halftime to up 25–24 with three minutes left in the fourth quarter, but they lost to the Arizona Cardinals by a score of 32–25 after quarterback Kurt Warner scored a last minute touchdown.\n', 'BULLET::::- February 4 – The Philadelphia Eagles win their first Super Bowl in franchise history by defeating the New England Patriots, 41-33, in Super Bowl LII, ending a 57-year championship drought.\n', "The Philadelphia Eagles season was the franchise's 49th season in the National Football League, they made the postseason for the fourth straight season (first time in franchise history the Eagles had made the postseason four straight times). The team was coming off a Super Bowl loss to the Oakland Raiders the previous season. Because they made the Super Bowl in 1980, they were picked by many to not only reach the Super Bowl, but to win it as well. The Eagles began the 1981 season with 6 straight wins, their best ever start to a season at the time. The Eagles would win then 3 of their next 5 games to sit at 9-2. They would then lose their next 4 games to slip to 9-6 and were in danger of missing out on the playoffs. The next week, they hammered the Cardinals 38-0 to clinch a playoff berth for the fourth straight season. In the playoffs, they met their arch rivals the Giants. It was New York's first playoff appearance in 18 years. In the game, the Giants would stun the eagles 27-21, ending the Eagles season as well as hopes for a second straight Super Bowl appearance. The Eagles would not make the playoffs again until 1988. They also wouldn't reach the Super Bowl again until 2004.\n", 'The Eagles defeated the New England Patriots by a score of 41–33 in Super Bowl LII for their first Super Bowl victory in franchise history. It was also their fourth NFL Championship, and their first league title since 1960. This was the second time the Eagles and Patriots battled in a Super Bowl; when they met in Super Bowl XXXIX, the Patriots won 24–21. Backup quarterback Nick Foles was named Super Bowl MVP and became the first backup to receive this award since his opponent, Tom Brady, did so in Super Bowl XXXVI 15 years earlier. The Eagles defeated both Super Bowl teams from the previous NFL season (the New England Patriots and the Atlanta Falcons) in the playoffs, the third team to beat both of them this season, after the Carolina Panthers and Miami Dolphins. They also defeated both teams who had beaten them in their only two previous Super Bowl appearances: the Oakland Raiders in the regular season, who beat them in Super Bowl XV, and the Patriots in the Super Bowl, who previously beat them in Super Bowl XXXIX.\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model from these passages, 
which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

To enhance the model's understanding of the question regarding when the Eagles won the Super Bowl, we can extract and analyze several key pieces of information from the provided passages. This content not only provides context about the Eagles' Super Bowl victory but also includes historical background that may be unfamiliar to the model. Here’s a breakdown of the relevant content and its significance:

### Extracted Content:

1. **Super Bowl LII Details**:
   - The Eagles defeated the New England Patriots by a score of 41–33 in Super Bowl LII on February 4, 2018. This victory marked the Eagles' first Super Bowl win in franchise history.
   - The game took place at U.S. Bank Stadium in Minneapolis, Minnesota.

2. **Historical Context**:
   - The Eagles had not won a championship since 1960, which was the last time they secured an NFL title before the Super Bowl era began.
   - The Eagles had previously lost two Super Bowls: one to the Oakland Raiders and another to the New England Patriots in Super Bowl XXXIX.

3. **Cultural Significance**:
   - The victory ended a 57-year championship drought for the franchise, which had been associated with a so-called "curse" stemming from their 1960 championship win against Vince Lombardi's Green Bay Packers.
   - The Eagles' win was celebrated widely in Philadelphia, highlighting the emotional significance of the victory for the team's fan base.

4. **Notable Players**:
   - Backup quarterback Nick Foles was named Super Bowl MVP, becoming the first backup to receive this award since Tom Brady in Super Bowl XXXVI.

5. **Franchise History**:
   - The Eagles had previously made the playoffs for four consecutive seasons leading up to their Super Bowl win, indicating a period of competitive success for the team.

### Analysis of the Role of This Content:

- **Temporal Context**: The specific date of the Super Bowl win (February 4, 2018) is crucial for answering the question directly. It anchors the event in time and allows for a clear understanding of when this significant achievement occurred.

- **Historical Significance**: Understanding the Eagles' long history of playoff heartbreak and their previous Super Bowl losses provides depth to the narrative of their eventual victory. This context can help the model appreciate the emotional weight of the win for fans and the franchise.

- **Cultural Impact**: The mention of the "curse" and the celebrations in Philadelphia illustrates the broader cultural implications of sports victories, particularly in cities with passionate fan bases. This can inform the model about the social dynamics surrounding sports events.

- **Player Recognition**: Highlighting Nick Foles' achievement as Super Bowl MVP adds a personal element to the narrative, showcasing individual excellence within the context of a team sport. This can help the model understand the significance of player contributions to team success.

- **Franchise Development**: The information about the Eagles' playoff appearances leading up to the Super Bowl win indicates a trajectory of improvement and competitiveness, which is important for understanding the team's evolution over time.

In summary, the extracted content provides a comprehensive background that enhances the model's understanding of the Eagles' Super Bowl victory, situating it within a broader historical, cultural, and emotional context. This enriched understanding can lead to more nuanced responses to questions about the Eagles and their achievements.

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

To determine when the Philadelphia Eagles won the Super Bowl, I need to consider the history of the Super Bowl and the specific years in which the Eagles participated. The Eagles have a notable history in the NFL, having reached the Super Bowl multiple times but only securing their first championship in Super Bowl LII. 

1. **Super Bowl LII Details**: The Eagles played against the New England Patriots on February 4, 2018, at U.S. Bank Stadium in Minneapolis, Minnesota. They won the game with a score of 41–33, marking their first Super Bowl victory in franchise history.

2. **Historical Context**: Prior to this victory, the Eagles had not won a championship since 1960, which was before the Super Bowl era began. They had previously lost in two Super Bowl appearances: one against the Oakland Raiders and another against the New England Patriots in Super Bowl XXXIX.

3. **Cultural Significance**: The Eagles' win in 2018 ended a 57-year championship drought, which had been associated with a so-called "curse" linked to their 1960 championship win against Vince Lombardi's Green Bay Packers. This victory was celebrated extensively in Philadelphia, highlighting its emotional significance for the fans.

5. **Franchise History**: The Eagles had made the playoffs for four consecutive seasons leading up to their Super Bowl win, indicating a period of competitive success and resilience for the team.

By synthesizing this information, I can provide a comprehensive answer that not only states the date of the Eagles' Super Bowl win but also contextualizes its significance within the franchise's history and the broader cultural landscape of sports.

### Answer:
The Philadelphia Eagles won the Super Bowl on February 4, 2018, defeating the New England Patriots 41–33 in Super Bowl LII. This victory marked the Eagles' first Super Bowl win in franchise history and ended a 57-year championship drought.

To answer the question "When did the Eagles win the Super Bowl?", we can extract and synthesize relevant information from the provided passages. 

1. **Date and Event**: The Philadelphia Eagles won their first Super Bowl on **February 4, 2018**, defeating the New England Patriots with a score of **41–33** in **Super Bowl LII**. This victory marked a significant milestone for the franchise, as it was their first Super Bowl win in history and their first NFL championship since 1960.

2. **Historical Context**: The Eagles had a long history of playoff heartbreak and had previously lost two Super Bowls (Super Bowl XV and Super Bowl XXXIX). The win in 2018 ended a 57-year championship drought for the team, which had been a source of frustration for their fan base, often referred to in the context of an alleged "curse" stemming from their last championship win in 1960.

3. **Significance of the Win**: The victory in Super Bowl LII was not only a triumph for the Eagles but also a cultural moment for Philadelphia, as it sent the city into wild celebrations. The win was particularly notable because it was achieved against a team (the Patriots) that had previously defeated them in a Super Bowl (Super Bowl XXXIX).

4. **Key Players and Performance**: Backup quarterback **Nick Foles** played a pivotal role in the victory, being named the Super Bowl MVP. His performance was historic as he became the first backup quarterback to win the MVP award since Tom Brady did so in Super Bowl XXXVI.

5. **Broader Context**: The Eagles' win in 2018 can be seen as a culmination of years of effort, including multiple playoff appearances and a strong season leading up to the Super Bowl. The context of the team's previous struggles adds depth to the significance of their 2018 victory.

In summary, the Philadelphia Eagles won the Super Bowl on **February 4, 2018**, defeating the New England Patriots in Super Bowl LII. This victory was a historic moment for the franchise, ending a long championship drought and providing a sense of redemption after previous losses in the Super Bowl. The context of their struggles and the cultural impact of the win further enrich the understanding of this achievement.

4. **Performance Metrics**: By noting the importance of individual performances (like Foles being named MVP), the model can learn to assess how individual contributions can influence collective success, enhancing its ability to evaluate scenarios where multiple factors contribute to an outcome.

5. **Historical Patterns**: The model can recognize patterns in sports history, such as the cyclical nature of team success and failure, which can inform its reasoning about future events based on historical data.

### Conclusion:
By consolidating and analyzing the extracted information, the model can improve its causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities. It can learn to identify and analyze relationships between events, understand the significance of context, and evaluate the impact of individual contributions within a team dynamic. This enhanced reasoning ability can be applied to a variety of domains beyond sports, including social sciences, economics, and decision-making processes.

Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.

when did the eagles win the super bowl

['The Eagles defeated the New England Patriots by a score of 41–33 in Super Bowl LII at U.S. Bank Stadium in Minneapolis, Minnesota on February 4, 2018, ending the alleged curse.\n', "The Eagles went on to win Super Bowl LII, 41–33. It was the team's first NFL championship since 1960, and first ever Super Bowl win.\n", "On January 23, 2005, the Eagles reached a fourth consecutive conference championship game (the first time this happened in the salary cap era of the NFL). At long last, the Eagles justified the hopes of their long-suffering fan base, defeating Michael Vick's much-hyped Atlanta Falcons, 27-10, sending them to their first Super Bowl in 24 years. The victory sent the city of Philadelphia into wild celebrations.\n", 'On February 4, 2018, the Philadelphia Eagles defeated the New England Patriots in Super Bowl LII 41-33 to win their first Super Bowl in team history, and first championship since the 1960 NFL Championship.\n', 'The Eagles have won four league titles. Three of these were won prior to the start of the Super Bowl era (in 1948, 1949, and 1960). The fourth and most recent championship was won in Super Bowl LII.\n', "This alleged curse supposedly prevented the Philadelphia Eagles franchise from winning a Super Bowl game. The origin of this curse dates back to 1960, when the Eagles defeated Vince Lombardi and the Green Bay Packers in the 1960 NFL Championship Game. This would be the only playoff loss in Lombardi's coaching career. Following Lombardi's death in 1970, the league honored his legacy by naming the Super Bowl trophy after him. This renaming, combined with the Eagles inability to win another championship after their 1960 victory, led some Eagles fans to believe the franchise was cursed by Vince Lombardi; that beating Lombardi meant never winning the trophy named after him. During that time, the Eagles accumulated a lot of playoff heartbreak, including 2 Super Bowl losses to the Oakland Raiders and New England Patriots, and 3 consecutive NFC Championship Game losses from 2001-2003. \n", 'On January 11, 2009, the team defeated the defending Super Bowl champion New York Giants 23–11 en route to their sixth NFC Championship Game. In the NFC Championship, the Eagles made a rally, going from down 24–6 at halftime to up 25–24 with three minutes left in the fourth quarter, but they lost to the Arizona Cardinals by a score of 32–25 after quarterback Kurt Warner scored a last minute touchdown.\n', 'BULLET::::- February 4 – The Philadelphia Eagles win their first Super Bowl in franchise history by defeating the New England Patriots, 41-33, in Super Bowl LII, ending a 57-year championship drought.\n', "The Philadelphia Eagles season was the franchise's 49th season in the National Football League, they made the postseason for the fourth straight season (first time in franchise history the Eagles had made the postseason four straight times). The team was coming off a Super Bowl loss to the Oakland Raiders the previous season. Because they made the Super Bowl in 1980, they were picked by many to not only reach the Super Bowl, but to win it as well. The Eagles began the 1981 season with 6 straight wins, their best ever start to a season at the time. The Eagles would win then 3 of their next 5 games to sit at 9-2. They would then lose their next 4 games to slip to 9-6 and were in danger of missing out on the playoffs. The next week, they hammered the Cardinals 38-0 to clinch a playoff berth for the fourth straight season. In the playoffs, they met their arch rivals the Giants. It was New York's first playoff appearance in 18 years. In the game, the Giants would stun the eagles 27-21, ending the Eagles season as well as hopes for a second straight Super Bowl appearance. The Eagles would not make the playoffs again until 1988. They also wouldn't reach the Super Bowl again until 2004.\n", 'The Eagles defeated the New England Patriots by a score of 41–33 in Super Bowl LII for their first Super Bowl victory in franchise history. It was also their fourth NFL Championship, and their first league title since 1960. This was the second time the Eagles and Patriots battled in a Super Bowl; when they met in Super Bowl XXXIX, the Patriots won 24–21. Backup quarterback Nick Foles was named Super Bowl MVP and became the first backup to receive this award since his opponent, Tom Brady, did so in Super Bowl XXXVI 15 years earlier. The Eagles defeated both Super Bowl teams from the previous NFL season (the New England Patriots and the Atlanta Falcons) in the playoffs, the third team to beat both of them this season, after the Carolina Panthers and Miami Dolphins. They also defeated both teams who had beaten them in their only two previous Super Bowl appearances: the Oakland Raiders in the regular season, who beat them in Super Bowl XV, and the Patriots in the Super Bowl, who previously beat them in Super Bowl XXXIX.\n']

question_info.question: when did the eagles win the super bowl
passages:
The Eagles defeated the New England Patriots by a score of 41–33 in Super Bowl LII at U.S. Bank Stadium in Minneapolis, Minnesota on February 4, 2018, ending the alleged curse.
The Eagles went on to win Super Bowl LII, 41–33. It was the team's first NFL championship since 1960, and first ever Super Bowl win.
On January 23, 2005, the Eagles reached a fourth consecutive conference championship game (the first time this happened in the salary cap era of the NFL). At long last, the Eagles justified the hopes of their long-suffering fan base, defeating Michael Vick's much-hyped Atlanta Falcons, 27-10, sending them to their first Super Bowl in 24 years. The victory sent the city of Philadelphia into wild celebrations.
On February 4, 2018, the Philadelphia Eagles defeated the New England Patriots in Super Bowl LII 41-33 to win their first Super Bowl in team history, and first championship since the 1960 NFL Championship.
The Eagles have won four league titles. Three of these were won prior to the start of the Super Bowl era (in 1948, 1949, and 1960). The fourth and most recent championship was won in Super Bowl LII.
This alleged curse supposedly prevented the Philadelphia Eagles franchise from winning a Super Bowl game. The origin of this curse dates back to 1960, when the Eagles defeated Vince Lombardi and the Green Bay Packers in the 1960 NFL Championship Game. This would be the only playoff loss in Lombardi's coaching career. Following Lombardi's death in 1970, the league honored his legacy by naming the Super Bowl trophy after him. This renaming, combined with the Eagles inability to win another championship after their 1960 victory, led some Eagles fans to believe the franchise was cursed by Vince Lombardi; that beating Lombardi meant never winning the trophy named after him. During that time, the Eagles accumulated a lot of playoff heartbreak, including 2 Super Bowl losses to the Oakland Raiders and New England Patriots, and 3 consecutive NFC Championship Game losses from 2001-2003. 
On January 11, 2009, the team defeated the defending Super Bowl champion New York Giants 23–11 en route to their sixth NFC Championship Game. In the NFC Championship, the Eagles made a rally, going from down 24–6 at halftime to up 25–24 with three minutes left in the fourth quarter, but they lost to the Arizona Cardinals by a score of 32–25 after quarterback Kurt Warner scored a last minute touchdown.
BULLET::::- February 4 – The Philadelphia Eagles win their first Super Bowl in franchise history by defeating the New England Patriots, 41-33, in Super Bowl LII, ending a 57-year championship drought.
The Philadelphia Eagles season was the franchise's 49th season in the National Football League, they made the postseason for the fourth straight season (first time in franchise history the Eagles had made the postseason four straight times). The team was coming off a Super Bowl loss to the Oakland Raiders the previous season. Because they made the Super Bowl in 1980, they were picked by many to not only reach the Super Bowl, but to win it as well. The Eagles began the 1981 season with 6 straight wins, their best ever start to a season at the time. The Eagles would win then 3 of their next 5 games to sit at 9-2. They would then lose their next 4 games to slip to 9-6 and were in danger of missing out on the playoffs. The next week, they hammered the Cardinals 38-0 to clinch a playoff berth for the fourth straight season. In the playoffs, they met their arch rivals the Giants. It was New York's first playoff appearance in 18 years. In the game, the Giants would stun the eagles 27-21, ending the Eagles season as well as hopes for a second straight Super Bowl appearance. The Eagles would not make the playoffs again until 1988. They also wouldn't reach the Super Bowl again until 2004.
The Eagles defeated the New England Patriots by a score of 41–33 in Super Bowl LII for their first Super Bowl victory in franchise history. It was also their fourth NFL Championship, and their first league title since 1960. This was the second time the Eagles and Patriots battled in a Super Bowl; when they met in Super Bowl XXXIX, the Patriots won 24–21. Backup quarterback Nick Foles was named Super Bowl MVP and became the first backup to receive this award since his opponent, Tom Brady, did so in Super Bowl XXXVI 15 years earlier. The Eagles defeated both Super Bowl teams from the previous NFL season (the New England Patriots and the Atlanta Falcons) in the playoffs, the third team to beat both of them this season, after the Carolina Panthers and Miami Dolphins. They also defeated both teams who had beaten them in their only two previous Super Bowl appearances: the Oakland Raiders in the regular season, who beat them in Super Bowl XV, and the Patriots in the Super Bowl, who previously beat them in Super Bowl XXXIX.
